summary: This is a 2019 court opinion and order from the Southern District of Florida regarding motions in the civil case Jane Doe 1 and Jane Doe 2 v. United States. It details the factual background of Jeffrey Epstein's sexual abuse of minors, the 2005-2008 investigation, and the secretive 2007 negotiations that led to a Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) between the U.S. Attorney's Office and Epstein's attorneys, which was kept from the victims in violation of the Crime Victims' Rights Act. This document is part of a court filing (likely a motion for summary judgment or related pleading) detailing the timeline of events and communications surrounding the 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) between Jeffrey Epstein and the U.S. Attorney's Office. It focuses on disputes over victim notification under the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA), revealing efforts by Epstein's defense team to delay or limit notifications and the government's internal conflicts over its legal obligations. This is a court order (Document 435) from the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida, granting partial summary judgment to Jane Doe 1 and Jane Doe 2. The court finds the U.S. Government violated the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA) by entering into a Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) with Jeffrey Epstein without conferring with the victims. The order details the legal standard for summary judgment and the court's reasoning regarding the government's obligations under the CVRA.

persons.name: Jane Doe 1

events.title: Initial Police Complaint
events.description: The Town of Palm Beach Police Department received a complaint from parents of a 14-year-old girl about sexual abuse by Jeffrey Epstein, leading to the identification of approximately 20 minor victims.

events.title: FBI Investigation Opened
events.description: At the request of Palm Beach police, the FBI opened an investigation into Epstein and his assistants for using interstate commerce to induce minors into illegal sexual activities.

events.title: Secret NPA Negotiations
events.description: Extended negotiations between the U.S. Attorney's Office and Epstein's defense team, conducted largely via email, resulting in a Non-Prosecution Agreement that was deliberately kept secret from the victims.

events.title: Jane Doe 1 Provides Information to FBI
events.description: Jane Doe 1 provided information about her abuse and Jane Doe 2's abuse to the FBI.

events.title: Non-Prosecution Agreement Executed
events.description: Epstein and the U.S. Attorney's Office formally entered into a Non-Prosecution Agreement, deferring federal prosecution in favor of state prosecution. The agreement granted immunity to Epstein and potential co-conspirators.

events.title: FBI Agents Inform Jane Doe 1 of State Plea
events.description: FBI agents met with Jane Doe 1 to explain Epstein would plead guilty to state charges, but did not fully explain that the federal NPA had already been signed, leading her to believe the federal investigation continued.

events.title: Government Sends Draft Victim Notification
events.description: The Government sent an email to defense attorney Lefkowitz attaching a draft victim notification letter dated November 29, 2007, outlining terms of the NPA.

events.title: Defense Objects to Victim Notification
events.description: Lefkowitz sent a letter to U.S. Attorney Acosta objecting to the proposed victim notification letter, arguing it was inappropriate before Epstein's plea or sentencing.

events.title: Starr Objects to Notification Process
events.description: Defense attorney Kenneth Starr sent a letter to Acosta objecting to the victim notification letter and complaining about not being afforded review rights.

events.title: Misleading FBI Letters Sent to Victims
events.description: The FBI sent letters to Jane Doe 1 and Jane Doe 2 stating the case was 'currently under investigation,' not disclosing the existence of the NPA.

events.title: Jane Doe 1 Meets with FBI and AUSA
events.description: Jane Doe 1 met with FBI Agents and an AUSA, providing details of Epstein's sexual abuse; the AUSA did not disclose the already-negotiated NPA.

events.title: Epstein Pleads Guilty in State Court
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein pled guilty to state law solicitation of prostitution charges, as part of the resolution under the NPA.

events.title: Jane Doe 1 Files Emergency CVRA Petition
events.description: Jane Doe 1 filed an emergency petition for enforcement of her rights under the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA).

events.title: Victims Receive Partial NPA Notification
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office sent victim notification letters to Jane Doe 1, Jane Doe 5, and others, explaining some civil compensation provisions but not the full NPA.

events.title: Jane Doe 2 Receives NPA Copy
events.description: The line prosecutor provided a copy of the NPA to attorney Bradley Edwards, informing Jane Doe 2 of its contents for the first time.

events.title: Government Letters to Victims
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office sent letters to victims (including Jane Doe 1 and 2) counseling 'patience' with the investigation, even though it had already bound itself to the Non-Prosecution Agreement with Epstein.

events.title: Jane Doe 2 Recognized as Victim
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office sent Jane Doe 2 a CVRA letter, formally recognizing her as a crime victim in the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Court Grants Partial Summary Judgment on CVRA Violation
events.description: Judge Kenneth A. Marra issues an order granting Jane Doe 1 and Jane Doe 2's motion for partial summary judgment, ruling the U.S. Government violated their rights under the CVRA by not conferring with them before entering into the NPA with Epstein.

locations: United States District Court in Miami
West Palm Beach, Palm Beach County, Florida
keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein sexually abused more than 30 minor girls between 1999 and 2007, and used paid employees to find and bring girls to him.

The 2007 Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) was negotiated in secret between the U.S. Attorney's Office and Epstein's lawyers, and the victims were not consulted or informed, violating the Crime Victims' Rights Act.
The NPA granted Epstein and any 'potential co-conspirators' immunity from federal prosecution and contained a clause to keep the agreement confidential and out of the public record.
Epstein's defense team, led by Jay Lefkowitz, actively sought and received assurances from prosecutors, including U.S. Attorney Alex Acosta, that victims would not be contacted about the NPA.
The U.S. Attorney's Office had identified 34 confirmed minor victims by September 24, 2007, and had drafted an 82-page prosecution memo and a 53-page indictment before opting for the NPA.
The U.S. Attorney's Office, under Alexander Acosta, entered into a Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) with Jeffrey Epstein in September 2007, deferring federal prosecution in favor of state charges.

Epstein's defense team, including attorneys Kenneth Starr, Lilly Ann Sanchez, and Lefkowitz, repeatedly objected to and sought to delay victim notification letters required by the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA).
Victims, including Jane Doe 1 and Jane Doe 2, received misleading letters from the FBI in early 2008 stating the case was 'under investigation,' while the NPA had already been signed months earlier.
Attorney Bradley Edwards, representing victims, was not informed of the NPA's existence until July 2008 when the government filed a responsive pleading to an emergency CVRA petition.

The government acknowledged it had proof beyond a reasonable doubt that identified individuals were victims of Epstein's criminal conduct while they were minors, with evidence dating to at least 2001.

The court ruled the U.S. Government violated the Crime Victims' Rights Act (CVRA) by entering into a Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) with Jeffrey Epstein without conferring with the victims, Jane Doe 1 and Jane Doe 2.
The government concealed the existence of the NPA from the victims and sent them letters asking for 'patience' in the investigation after it had already bound itself to the agreement.

The court rejected the government's argument that Jane Doe 2 was not protected by the CVRA because she made early statements favorable to Epstein, stating unequivocally that she was a victim as she was sexually abused by Epstein as a minor.

The court's ruling is limited to finding a CVRA violation; it explicitly states it is not ruling on whether the decision not to prosecute was improper, nor on the appropriate remedy for the violation.

The order references prior rulings in the same case which established that victims of Epstein's federal sex offenses involving minors are crime victims under the CVRA and that the CVRA applies to pre-charge investigations and non-prosecution agreements.
